docs.lead_paragraph: The deadlock over the economic stimulus legislation makes one thing very clear: the health care wars have resumed with a vengeance. Washington policy makers are confronted with the dangerous combination of a recession, soaring health care costs and an uninsured population that was already close to 40 million last year and could grow substantially in the coming months, experts say. But the two parties are stubbornly divided over what to do about it.
docs.abstract: News analysis says deadlock over economic stimulus legislation makes it very clear that health care wars have resumed with vengeance; says policy makers are confronted with dangerous combination of recession, soaring health care costs and growing uninsured population that was already close to 40 million last year; says debate touches on some basic fault lines between parties, with Republicans wanting to use tax credits to help individuals buy insurance in open marketplace and Democrats wanting to shore up employer-based system with federal assistance and pump more money into Medicaid (M)
docs.snippet: The deadlock over the economic stimulus legislation makes one thing very clear: the health care wars have resumed with a vengeance.    Washington policy makers are confronted with the dangerous combination of a recession, soaring health care costs...

docs.lead_paragraph: A bid to give millions of Americans greater access to mental health care died in Congress tonight as House members rejected a Senate proposal to eliminate disparities in insurance coverage for mental and physical illnesses. The action followed 45 minutes of impassioned debate over the rights of people with mental disorders. ''This is one of the most important social and civil rights issues in the United States,'' said Senator Pete V. Domenici, Republican of New Mexico, who had offered the proposal approved by the Senate in October.

headline.main: Drive for More Mental Health Coverage Fails in Congress

docs.abstract: House members of conference committee reject Sen Pete V Domenici's Senate-passed bill to eliminate disparities in insurance coverage for mental and physical illnesses; 10-7 party-line vote comes after Domenici and Sen Paul Wellstone urge members to ban widespread limits on pyschiatric care; House Republicans, who oppose measure, cite cost; Pres Bush says he will work with Congress to devise way to cut coverage disparities without significantly increasing health costs (M)
docs.snippet: A bid to give millions of Americans greater access to mental health care died in Congress tonight as House members rejected a Senate proposal to eliminate disparities in insurance coverage for mental and physical illnesses.    The action followed 45...

docs.lead_paragraph: After more than half a century in business, the LTV Corporation will soon shut its doors, barring a government-supplied miracle. One of the nation's biggest steel makers, LTV put its mills earlier this month on what is called ''hot idle,'' which would allow the company to restart them quickly if a government-backed loan comes through at the last minute.

headline.main: LTV Seems on the Verge of a Shutdown

docs.abstract: LTV Corp will soon shut down after more than half century in business, barring government-supplied loan; company will ask bankruptcy judge to end its labor contract if help does not arrive by Dec 19; shutdown would leave about 70,000 retirees and recent employees with no or reduced pensions and health care benefits, and force government to pick up at least some of costs that remain; pension costs are at least $2 billion; LTV's management has concluded that its losses, $2 million per day, are simply too large; graph (M)
docs.snippet: After more than half a century in business, the LTV Corporation will soon shut its doors, barring a government-supplied miracle.    One of the nation's biggest steel makers, LTV put its mills earlier this month on what is called ''hot idle,'' which...

docs.lead_paragraph: Talks between the two parties in Congress on a proposed economic recovery package moved to the brink of collapse tonight, with Democrats and Republicans deeply divided over tax cuts and how best to deliver health insurance subsidies to the unemployed. After another day of fruitless back and forth, House Republican leaders said tonight that they would bring their own stimulus bill to the floor on Wednesday to highlight their plan and what they say has been a substantial effort on their part to compromise.

headline.main: Talks in Congress Break Down Over Health Benefit for Jobless

docs.abstract: Congressional talks on economic recovery package near collapse, with Republicans and Democrats deeply divided over tax cuts and health insurance subsidies for unemployed; House Republicans leaders say they will bring own stimulus bill to floor, move Democrats say would undermine any remaining chance of deal (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-18 Europe Seeking Unity On How to Press Arafat European leaders are struggling to forge a unified position that puts more pressure on the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, without undermining him. But the effort has been complicated by Bush administration appeals to European allies to distance themselves from Mr. Arafat. A8 India-Pakistan Verbal Exchange India's home minister, L. K. Advani, accused Pakistan's intelligence agency and two Islamic militant groups of seeking ''to wipe out the entire political leadership of India,'' referring to the recent attack on India's Parliament. Pakistan rejected the accusations and called Mr. Advani's remarks irresponsible, inflammatory and threatening. A18

docs.lead_paragraph: State Comptroller H. Carl McCall issued a report yesterday warning that the budget gap that New York City would face next year would be even worse than other officials had predicted: $4.7 billion, which is more than $1 billion larger than the gap forecast by the Giuliani administration. It was the second ominous forecast about the city's finances this week. On Monday, City Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi cautioned that the city's economy would shrink by 3.1 percent next year, its first yearlong decline in more than a decade, largely as a result of the attack on the World Trade Center.

headline.main: McCall Sees $4.7 Billion City Budget Gap

docs.abstract: New York State Comptroller H Carl McCall issues report warning New York City faces $4.7-billion budget gap next year, much more than $1 billion gap projected by Giuliani administration (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. Gary Locke proposed further spending cuts that would eliminate 30 programs and hundreds of jobs to cover the $1.25 billion shortfall in the state's two-year budget. The plan would eliminate 835 full-time jobs, and state employees would be asked to pay a greater percentage of their health insurance costs. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

headline.main: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Budget Cuts

docs.abstract: Washington Gov Gary Locke proposes spending cuts that would eliminate 30 programs and 835 jobs to cover $1.25 billion shortfall in two-year budget (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center. ROBERT EVANS Rob, Bob or Bobby If nicknames are a measure of affection, Robert Evans inspired plenty. ''To me he was Rob, to Mom he was Bob and to the rest of the world he was Bobby,'' said his sister, Jeanne Evans, who lived near her brother in Franklin Square, on Long Island. Firefighter Evans, 36, was also known as Jerry Lewis around the Engine Company 33 firehouse in Manhattan, a reference to his practical jokes and big heart. He often called his sister when he got home from work to say he was O.K., but once, catching her asleep, he decided to call back every 15 minutes. (To avoid retaliation, he then turned off his phone.)

headline.main: Living Large, Hanging Tough, Breaking Ground and Loving the Flag
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: PORTRAITS OF GRIEF: THE VICTIMS

docs.lead_paragraph: Republicans and Democrats headed into the final steps of their negotiations over an economic recovery package today, seeking a final round of talks even as they pursued strategies to blame each other if they failed. Senator Tom Daschle, Democrat of South Dakota, the majority leader, called President Bush and Speaker J. Dennis Hastert, Republican of Illinois, in an effort to break the latest deadlock in the negotiations.

headline.main: Parties Press Effort to Pass Stimulus Plan

docs.abstract: Republicans and Democrats head into final steps of negotiations over economic recovery package, seeking final round of talks even as they pursue strategies to blame each other if they fail (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Congress is dispensing last-minute legislative favors before it adjourns for the year, and lobbyists for special interests have lined up with a long list of requests, some of which raise major questions about the proper role of government in a weak economy. Flight schools, skydiving companies, manufacturers of small aircraft and operators of small airports are seeking a $7.5 billion package of grants and loans to compensate them for business lost since the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11. A House subcommittee approved the legislation, the General Aviation Reparations Act, last week.

headline.main: Lobby Groups Find Congress In Giving Mood

docs.abstract: Lobbyists for special interests find Congress willing to dispense last-minute legislative favors before it adjourns for year, raising questions about proper role of government in weak economy; some Senators object, calling some of proposals special-interest legislation; several factors lead to large number of proposals for aid: Congress is in session later than usual, and events of Sept 11 have galvanized industries into action (M)
